qas.question: Who pioneered research that led to the new ANSI values?
What standards were the ANSI developed from?

answers.text: Weston film speed ratings and General Electric film values

qas.question: What types of film did the ANSI measure?
When did the ANSI define its new measure?
What were ANSI values often called in the beginning?

answers.text: American standard speed numbers or ASA exposure-index numbers

qas.question: Who did research for General Electric?

plausible_answers.text: earlier research work by Loyd Ancile Jones

qas.question: What were the Weston Film speed ratings inspired by?
When did Jones publish his research?

context: Based on <b7_0>earlier research work by <a0_0><b5_0>Loyd Ancile Jones<b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> (1884–1954) of Kodak and inspired by the systems of <a1_0>Weston film speed ratings and General Electric film values<a1_0/>, the American Standards Association (now named <b6_0>ANSI<b6_0/>) defined a new method to determine and specify film speeds of <a2_0>black-and-white negative films<a2_0/> in <a3_0><b8_0>1943<b8_0/><a3_0/>. ASA Z38.2.1-1943 was revised in 1946 and <b9_0>1947<b9_0/> before the standard grew into ASA PH2.5-1954. Originally, ASA values were frequently referred to as <a4_0>American standard speed numbers or ASA exposure-index numbers<a4_0/>. (See also: Exposure Index (EI).)
